title: Revealed: How much more you'll be paying on your mortgage when interest rates rise
text:
Revealed: How much more you'll be paying on your mortgage when interest rates rise Revealed: How much more you'll be paying on your mortgage when interest rates rise THE era of low interest rates is drawing to a close and homeowners in London face the biggest rise in mortgage payments, according to analysis. PUBLISHED: 17:29, Fri, Aug 7, 2015 | UPDATED: 18:27, Fri, Aug 7, 2015 GETTY Interest rates could sooon rise 
Households have told to prepare changes to their mortgage after the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) this month was split over whether rates should be hiked immediately. Amid a continued economic recovery, it's now thought to be only a matter of time before members of the committee reach a consensus that Base Rate should move above its six-year low of 0.5 per cent. The Bank's Governor Mark Carney said rises will be slow and gradual when they happen, but homeowners have been urged not to be complacent. Just a 0.25 per cent rise would increase the average mortgage repayment by £204 a year, according to comparison site comparethemarket.com And a hike of 0.5 per cent would typically cost families £420 a year. When the Base Rate increases the Bank's two per cent, households can expect to pay an additional £148 in repayments every month, amounting to a hefty £1,776 a year. A look at how homeowners across the country will be affected reveals that Londoner face the biggest strain when rates rise. However, families are facing larger mortgage bills even before a rise in central rates. Analysts have said that lenders are already reacting to prospect of increased rates and have started to remove some of their lowest priced mortgages from the market. The average two-year fixed rate at 60 per cent loan-to-value to rise from 1.75 per cent on the July 14 to 1.86 per cent, according to Moneyfacts.co.uk. In January there were just six rate increases, but in July this had jumped to 36. Related articles Britain in the red: Property debt grows to £1trillion amid warning... 
Consumers have been advised to now fix into a low rate while they still can.Charlotte Nelson, finance expert at Moneyfacts.co.uk said: "This just goes to show that we do not necessarily need a base rate rise for mortgage rates to go up, as there are many other economic forces in play."Borrowers should not rest on their laurels and will need to act fast, as these deals will not be around forever."
